Date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2024
Data:
A few years ago I bought two of the non-matter Nanoleaf A19 bulbs. They worked so well and had nearly instant responses from the HomeKit app. At the time I was using around 20 Hue A19 soft white bulbs and slowly over the last few years I’ve been having my Hue bulbs burn out. I wasn’t replacing them and got to the point I needed to do something. So I ordered 16 Nanoleaf “Matter” bulbs thinking I’d have great performance like my “HomeKit” versions and also color bulbs rather than soft white that I had with Hue.
I have had nothing but issues since installing. I have never experienced such terrible smart home products. I have tried connecting via Nanoleaf app, HomeKit app, turning off cloud sync, factory refreshing, moving bulbs around to different locations, nothing has worked. If I create a scene in HomeKit, the bulbs randomly change brightness color and almost change in a “choppy” non smooth fashion. Hue bulbs and normal “dumb” dimmers typically have a smooth dimming feature, not these bulbs. They will take multiple steps to dim to where I set it to - might be that I go from 100% down to 20% and the bulbs will suddenly jump to 80 - 60 - 20 or something like that, not in sync, all random and very choppy. I’ve got grouped accessories (3 bulbs per fixture) and each bulb in the group changes independently of the others. Occasionally some change to different colors during the dimming/off/on procedure. There is no explanation to this. I hesitate to make any changes in HomeKit and if there is a scene set I typically need to run it multiple times before it sets correctly.
Lastly I had at least one bulb that would visibly “glow” after showing as off in HomeKit or Nanoleaf apps. I tried factory resetting and moving this bulb and no changes. There could have been more that did this, it was just the one bulb that was in a fixture right above my bed, so every night I could see it glowing in a dark room. Nanoleaf didn’t seem to care about this even after a video and picture. It has a visible glow in a dark room and getting video and picture of this is difficult but even in my evidence it showed a glowing orb in a fixture of 3 bulbs.
I have sent numerous emails to Nanoleaf, spent hours and hours troubleshooting, and there is no solution from them. They tried claiming their engineers were working on a solution which I had no idea was even released because even after it released the bulbs still didn’t work right. Nanoleaf support has run me around in circles, having new people respond to me and act like my ticket didn’t have enough reported data already and they’d ask me to do the standard troubleshooting actions every time I responded or send another list, screenshot, video, etc. The lack of care in the problem was astounding and their support was unwilling to provide help beyond copy/paste support replies.
I don’t know how some of you are enjoying these bulbs. I bought 16 of them and not a single one performed like any other smart bulb I’ve ever tried. They were so bizarre in how they were acting it couldn’t have been just a bad batch, these are terribly engineered. Maybe it’s related to HomeKit and Matter and them not working - but save you money and go to Hue for consistency and an actual good product. Maybe if Nanoleaf decides to go back to their old design I’d be interested again, but these matter bulbs are 100% junk!

Dimmer is a good range, can get very dim.

Essential lights can only have a limited number of basic scenes (preset color patterns) on them.

So -
I really feel like these are great bulbs if you are already bought in to nanoleaf panels.
As standalone bulbs they are great white spectrum bulbs with beautiful if dim rgb colors, but they are very frustrating to use.

Data:
Pros:
- Rich color options with 16M+ RGBW colors
- Simple HomeKit setup
- More affordable compared to other smart bulbs on the market
Cons:
- Requires constant power to the lamp
- Response time can be slow
Insights:
The Nanoleaf Smart LED A19 is a versatile smart bulb that shines with its vibrant colors and easy integration with Apple HomeKit. However, its design only draws power from the lamp it is installed in. So, like all electronics, continuous power is crucial for maintaining its connection to HomeKit. If the lamp's power is turned off, then you will lose connectivity and all home automation integration. You must use the Apple Home app, Siri, or another compatible home automation platform to control the on/off function of the bulb. It's also worth noting that you may experience slower than expected response times when using this bulb with Apple HomeKit. On the positive side, it is considerably less expensive than other smart bulbs on the market. Overall the Nanoleaf Smart LED A19 is a solid choice for enhancing your smart home lighting.

Data:
I’ve been disappointed with color fading on these bulbs. I wanted some low ambient lighting that slowly fades colors. These tend more to hop/flash from color to color than to gently fade, and there is a limit how many steps a scene can contain, so you can’t fake it very easily either. It’s especially visible when they’re set dimmer than 100% bright.
Initially, I set these up using the Nanoleaf app. Then I realized I couldn’t automate them unless I got more kit, so I also bought a HomePod Mini, and set them up again using Home. They’re easy to set up either way.
Via Apple Home it was easy to automate them. They turn off at night if I forget, or turn themselves on when my phone is the first one into the home at night. It was easy to set some basic settings and now I can shout to Siri to turn on bright lights or “make the lights blue” or whatever.
The circadian setting in the Nanoleaf app is very good but I haven’t found a way to access it through Home. That is, if you want to use the circadian lighting, you have to do that via the Nanoleaf app every time, manually. Surely we could at least ask for a widget for this? But ultimately I want to be able to access that setting via Home because that’s where I automate from. It shouldn’t be so hard to say “turn on my light to the circadian setting for the current time of day,” but it’s not possible. Fingers crossed for an update.
I’m happy with how bright they are and my partner, an android guy, is not having any issues accessing them from his own hardware.
But for now, I’m mostly just turning them on and setting them to a solid color because the fades are so jarring, and that’s not why I got them or why I bought a HomePod Mini to go alongside them. So that’s disappointing and I think next time I’ll shop around more.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2023
Data:
TL;DR: the Nanoleaf app does just fine with these bulbs but it doesn't use Matter to communicate with them (!!!). So far my experience with these Matter-enabled bulbs has been significantly worse than the Essentials with HomeKit bulbs: each bulb took multiple tries to connect to my smart home ecosystem, requiring a factory reset of the bulb if it failed & Home Assistant control of the bulbs seems flaky.
Why 3 stars?
PROS:
- the response times are fast, thanks to Thread
- the bulbs are brighter & more energy efficient than the ones they replaced
- the bulbs can act as Thread routers
- my kids love the scenes you can set the lights on
CONS:
- initial setup was a PITA (-1.5)
- Home Assistant, my main smart home controller, regularly loses connection to the bulbs (probably not Nanoleaf's fault, so I'm not actually deducting any stars for this)
- the bulbs can't be grouped to avoid the popcorn effect when simultaneously controlling multiple bulbs in a single room (-0.5)
Who am I? A tinkerer who authored the initial Home Assistant integration for HomeKit over Thread, specifically to support my original Nanoleaf A19 Essentials bulbs.
Would I buy these (Matter BR30 bulbs) again? No, not right away at least. I do think that Thread-based protocols are the future & I want to support Nanoleaf, who has twice now done the right thing & replaced my Elements controller, even well past the warranty expiration for the second one (manufacturing/component issue they discovered in the power regulation section of the circuit board). Additionally, my favorite Zigbee BR30 bulb was discontinued & I didn't want to pay anywhere close to the price of these bulbs for a Zigbee bulb that couldn't route (I'm looking at you, Sengled). If money were no object, I would have replaced these 6 BR30 bulbs with a nice Zigbee bulb first and then upgraded to Matter at a later date. I don't tend to purchase temporary solutions, however, preferring to be economical with my money (says the person that just bought these $$$ bulbs when a cheapo dumb bulb would have been just fine).
Should you buy them? I would wait a few months or have lots of patience. You should have a Thread Border Router in a good location. Go in with low expectations and maybe your smart home ecosystem of choice will surprise you.
If you decide to purchase these bulbs, set them up one at a time in a lamp sitting right in front of you. First things first, onboard them to the Nanoleaf app & perform any firmware update you are asked to do. Then, go into the bulb's settings in the NL app and click the "connect to matter" button. On Android, it will pop up a list of apps that can pair over Matter. In my case this was Google, Alexa, and Home Assistant. After selecting Home Assistant, it was luck of the draw if the app was able to onboard the bulb. If it failed, clicking retry never worked; additionally, the app would not allow you to exit the flow and retry. A full factory reset of the bulb is required to try again. Anecdotally, I found that if the bulb was immediately connected to a Thread network, which was the second step the NL app did during initial pairing, my chances of success were significantly better to connect to the bulb using HA's Matter controller. Finally, I never had any success attempting the QR code or 11-digit code directly within HA but YMMV.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2024
Data:
To set the stage, I am in the Nanoleaf HomeKit system in a BIG way. Shapes. Elements. Lightstrips. Even a remote. And of course about twenty bulbs. Having them all work flawlessly with HomeKit was the major reason...a quality product with absolutely wonderful integration is something that I really valued. And I never had a cross word about Nanoleaf.
But here we are.
I'm not the kind of person who follows developments in this space overly religiously. I had the system, it works, end of story for me. However, one of my Essentials bulbs started flickering a bit, enough so that I figured it was an LED bank that was overheating or something, and hence a replacement is called for. Little did I know that I really should have stocked up and hoarded the HomeKit bulbs, because, well...
The Matter bulb is not as good. Worse in fact. Much worse.
Oddly enough, the catalyst for this review is the HomeKit adaptive lighting. It's really a great feature and one that not only works, but satisfies my OCD of having all lights in a room use the same color and temperature. When setting up the Matter version here...adaptive lighting via the Home app simply isn't there. And I believe I get why, being Matter is a particular protocol or whatever that's built around compatibility. So what I'm left with is trying to use the Nanoleaf version of adaptive lighting to get this to integrate VISUALLY, and not just SYSTEMICALLY. And this bulb absolutely fails.
To get it to work at least approximately as well as the HomeKit bulb, I had to manually fiddle with the bulb in the Nanoleaf app, itself a frustrating ordeal. For managing the hardware, the Nanoleaf app is really only good for downloading updates and finding interesting scenes. For pure hardware management, it's lousy. So an hour later I have it kind of, almost, but not quite set up to do the same things it only took me about ten minutes to do with the HomeKit bulb.
In short, I have an "upgrade" with less functionality than the original.
And this is sad. I have a LOT of HomeKit items from Nanoleaf, the majority of which (namely about twenty bulbs...) simply have no equivalent replacement from Nanoleaf. This leaves a very bad taste in my mouth as I contemplate future smart home maintenance. I'm sure the time will come shortly when I will have problems with the other bulbs in the house (wear and tear, lack of continued firmware updates, etc) and will give serious thought to bailing and going to another vendor. Not having native HomeKit integrations is really a deal breaker for me.
Epic fail, Nanoleaf.

Data:
At first I could not get these bulbs to work, but there is a fix for the issue in the Nanoleaf Knowledge base. Updating the firmware to version 3.6 via Bluetooth, fixes the problem. Once I updated the firmware I was able to get these bulbs to connect to my thread network and work as intended.
The Nanoleaf knowledgebase details the process:
*Factory reset the Nanoleaf Essentials product (leave unplug for 15 min first)
*Turn off Wi-Fi on your Phone (you still must have cellular access to download the firmware)
*Pair the Nanoleaf Essentials product to the Nanoleaf App (I had to take my lampshades off as they interfered with the Bluetooth signal)
*Go to More > My Devices and there should be an option to Update

Data:
I wanted to like these. They’re bright, have great colors, and they feel high quality in your hand. When you first set them up and they’re connected, they’re awesome. You’ll feel like a genius consumer, laughing to yourself as you remember the expensive hue bulbs you smugly scrolled past on your way down to nanoleaf.
Then an hour will go by and you’ll try to turn your lights off only to see “NO RESPONSE” in Homekit under one or more of your devices. No prob, you’ll think. I’ll just cycle the power and let them connect fresh. Yep that’ll work, for 20 minutes. Then back to NO RESPONSE. I’m exaggerating a bit, admittedly—sometimes they’ll work for short stretches of a day, day and a half. But inevitably, you’re headed back to NO RESPONSE town, and soon. Usually right when you *really* need the lights to turn on, like so you don’t trip over your dog in the dark. But they won’t turn on, and you will trip over your dog in the dark.
I know it’s not my wifi. I have a great mesh network with more nodes than my house needs. I even dedicated two of them to the nanoleafs ONLY via mac address filtering and still, no dice. My hub is the newest 4K apple TV. Oh, and all of my other IoT stuff works flawlessly. I should have said that first.
Anyway, I don’t normally write reviews but I felt like if I could save one hopeful person from having their hopes dashed like mine, then my frustration wouldn’t entirely be in vain. These bulbs are truly the epitome of “too good to be true” and I highly regret purchasing them. My stupidity led me to continue fussing with them until after the return date cutoff, so I’m stuck with them. They’re going in a drawer. Or maybe I’ll give them to an enemy.
You’re better off wicking up some oil and crafting a lantern. OK I’m finished. I’m just bummed, man!

Data:
I have Hue lights throughout my entire house (excluding bathroom, attic and closets), but I wanted to try out thread devices after switching to eero mesh routers. While I already knew these bulbs were going to have poor color brightness, I thought they would be good for adding adaptive lighting to fixtures/rooms of less importance.
I installed one for testing over the weekend on my back patio, which installed and updated after a couple tries. Then on Monday, after I tossed the box into the recycle bin, I paired up the other two bulbs. Neither of these bulbs would update and after re-adding them I was able to get a second bulb up to date. Data:
These bulbs are different than standard wifi smart bulbs in that they rely on the thread networks for communication and matter for protocol. Most smart home hubs from the mainline ecosystems (Amazon Alexa, Google Home, Samsung Smarthings, and Apple Homekit) all provide the thread network and matter controller. In theory, you simply add to your smart home and it works great.
In practice, nanoleaf has terrible firmware for their entire essential lines (see other comments about unresponsive devices). Nanoleaf has failed to properly implement the matter communication protocol which leads to the problems listed in other reviews. I would not recommend these to anyone; even if you're very familiar with networking and thread/matter, these are a nightmare, much less an average consumer. Nanoleaf has acknowledged the problem and promised for months to fix the issue via a firmware update, but that has yet to be seen.
If you do buy these, whatever you do, don't pair more than about 8-10 or they will destroy your thread network and potentially make it not only impossible to communicate with your bulbs, but also with your other thread devices.
The bulb hardware is great, too bad the firmware is terrible and they are borderline unusable.

Data:

To control for the cross platform inconsistencies, I eventually tried to exclusively use an Android device and I also tried to pair directly with Smartthings and Apple Home. None of these solutions worked.
Wouldn’t recommend.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2023
Data:
I bought 9 of these bulbs hoping to have a few outside and the rest inside. I have a Nest hub gen 2 that acts as the matter controller and thread border router. I powered on the lights one by one making sure the firmware was updated and I could control the light through Google home.
I then placed all the bulbs where they belonged but I could only see 5 of the 9 bulbs! I've waited days hoping it would take a bit for the thread mesh to figure it out but no luck. I can see two lights that are outside and 3 inside. The lights should act as mesh extenders so all my lights should connect.
That is not the case with these lightbulbs. This defeats the purpose of thread.
The only way I can control all my outside lights is if I stand next to them and control them over Bluetooth.
Stay away from these. This is a beta product and is no where near ready. The thread/matter support is a lie.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2022
Data:
I like the product when it works. However, they don’t work. Most of the time they are unreachable, meaning you can’t use Siri or the app to change the brightness, color, scene, etc. you know.. the whole reason one gets a smart bulb. Meaning these became very expensive light bulbs that could only be operated with the traditional light switch.
Troubleshooting was a pain and I had to do it far too often. Once the bulbs were reset and re-added back to the app and HomeKit, they worked for the rest of the day usually. Wake up.. unreachable again. I’ve had numerous smart bulbs and worked in tech for 10 years. I know exactly what to do. These are just junk bulbs.
Warranty.. what warranty? The seller who happens to be the manufacturer of the bulbs, did nothing to help resolve the situation. No offer of replacement bulbs or a refund. Thank goodness for Amazon customer service. Can’t tell you how disappointed I am with these knockoff bulbs from this knockoff company.
Overall, I was excited to try the nanoleaf bulbs. I had a Philips hue system for years and loved it. Sold my home and started trying different setups. There are better bulbs than these for cheaper. And if you want the best, go Philips hue. They’re expensive but worth it. They do more than every other bulb and never have issues.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 21, 2024
Data: I cannot recommend this product. I bought it because Nanoleaf is supposed to be a good company with good products. This however is is something to stay away from. I tired many different ways to connect this bulb with HomeKit and could not. I am sending it back. Nanoleaf wants you to download *their* app, sign in and add the bulb and supposedly it then gets added to HomeKit. Despite several tries, resets etc, it would not add to HomeKit. Their app is nothing but a poor copy of HomeKit not to mention a store trying to sell you more of their stuff. I have installed other Matter-enabled and non-matter-enabled devices in HomeKit without having to download a proprietary app, as it should be. Meross outlets and bulbs all install flawlessly directly into the Apple Home app. Ill stick with companies that want it to work right more than trying to harvest your information.

Data:

Honestly, don't buy if you plan on using Alexa, just save yourself the hassle.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2023
Data: I don't often trash a company or a product, but these lightbulbs are absolute garbage. 5 bulbs, connected to thread via a Nest Hub Max border router, and they are constantly going offline. My place is only 1500 square feet, and the bulbs are optimally placed for a Thread network, but even the one that's 5 feet from the border router goes offline constantly. It's definitely not my local WiFi either as I'm pulling 1.2 Gbps internet speed over WiFi. I've worked in various IT and IT Security jobs for 23 years, and even I got sick of troubleshooting and trying to make these work. These are by far the worst smart devices of all the ones I've placed in my home. After several days of frustration, I decided to return them and replace them with the Philips Hue bulbs and hub. I have not had a single issue with the Hue bulbs so far. I was excited about the potential for Thread, but it just isn't reliable at all.

Data:
Try Philips Hue as an alternative. It can't be any worse than these.

Data: I bought this bulb because I thought it would do basic smart features like Philips Hue, such as setting timers to have the bulb come on and off at certain hours, at a certain color and brightness, or to turn off after a set number of minutes. These bulbs cannot do this unless you have additional equipment such as an Apple HomePod, Apple TV, Google Home, etc which is completely ridiculous! Data:
I purchased these bulbs to avoid having to get a Hue Bridge or similar product and just utilize Thread via a Nest Hub and HomePod Mini that I already had.

I had to try numerous times before I could get them added. Even after I got them added, there were numerous connectivity issues, to the point where I had to remove and re-add a bulb. There’s also the issue of light switches. While you will have this problem with any smart bulb, they require power to enable their smart features, so a dumb switch will disable that. You either need a smart switch that works properly with smart bulbs (I’ve seen people reference Inovelli for this, though I personally haven’t tried them) or just just have to leave the light switches on and control the lights via your mobile device/voice command exclusively.
The experience has been far from smooth. I expected more consistent connectivity and responsiveness, but so far it’s been a mixed bag.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2021
Data:
I bought these purely on the grounds that I wanted my IoT hardware to be future-proofed, and so should be Thread-based. Turns out that is not a great strategy! Just because a company is forward-looking enough to use Thread doesn't mean they get the rest of the system correct...
The biggest problem with these lights is they flicker. I don't understand what the issue here is. Can no-one build an LED light that doesn't flicker? Just put a damn capacitor in the bulb! This is not rocket science.
Of my 7 Hue bulbs, two ambiance and one color flicker if I drive them at higher than 90% brightness; one hue white flickers if driven at below 70% brightness.
The Nanoleaf I was sent flickers at ANY brightness when at a high color temperature (ie blueish-white) and at anything below about 80% brightness when at a low color temperature. This is not acceptable!
A secondary problem is that it's very slow to respond to HomeKit commands, but I am willing to overlook that for now as it may reflect the distance between the bulb and my Apple TV. Let's see if it gets better as my Thread network fills in.
FWIW of all smartbulbs I have tried
- Hue (as HomeKit) were easy to set up -- but after a few years half have degenerated to some form of flicker unless I keep them in a certain brightness range
- Nanoleaf also easy to set up -- and flickering right out the gate.
- Wyze -- nicely bright, no flicker so far after about two years with two bulb sample. But not HomeKit, so irritating WiFi setup, and I have to use HomeBridge. All communication goes through a server (not local) which once a day decides to reject my authentication token, and I have to try the request again. So 100% for hardware, 0% for software. And being non-HomeKit, you don't get Apple's time of day dependent color temperature.
- Probably the best overall have been Ikea. Again you need HomeBridge, and you have to go through the pain of Ikea's weird Zigbee setup and their weird mental model of how lights are associated with controllers are associated with rooms. But the lights are *mostly* bulletproof once set up, and are extremely cheap.
If whatever I buy lands up sucking one way or another then you might as well pay less for the suckitude.
I think Ikea based on Thread will be the winner once they finally make that switch. Sure, you'll need HomeBridge probably, but if you're already doing that at least you get a bulb that doesn't flicker, is bright enough, and doesn't randomly stop working for dumb reasons.
But damn, it's a sorry indictment of this space that we've been at this for almost 10 years (the first Hue's came out in 2012) and you still cannot buy a product that doesn't suck, whether you are willing to pay at the high end (Hue), midrange (Nanoleaf) or the low end (Wyze or Ikea).

Data:
I did not buy these bulbs on Amazon, instead I bought a few 3-packs at a local hardware store but here is my review.
Pros: easy to install/integrate with HomeKit, matter/thread enabled, price point.
cons: colors are bit washed out
new review as of 05/22/2024:
About a month before this updated review, Nanoleaf pushed out an update to all bulbs/lightstrips to version 3.6.173 and since then, connectivity and reliability of all bulbs have improved 99%. Since the update, the bulbs have never gone offline and become "unreachable" (that I've seen anyways). Since the update, the only time I've seen them as unresponsive (lightstrip was only device offline) is when I review thread network using the Eve Home app, but even then, the downtime was no more than 2 minutes. Looks like the update resolved all the issues I was having and for that, I thank Nanoleaf. It has been a month since update, so i feel confident recommending these bulbs.
old review below:
I cannot recommend these bulbs, especially at the absurd price of $20/bulb (not even Hue bulbs run that much). Until connectivity issues are addressed via future firmware update, this product is barely worth 2 stars (mind you, i never rate anything one star, ever). If you do purchase, your milage will vary. I have 15 nanoleaf bulbs and sometimes, they all go offline for no reason. it's as if any chatter on the network confuses the bulbs. my mesh network is quite robust, there's no reason any of these bulbs should lose connection to their parent router.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on May 27, 2024
Data:
I ordered a three pack of these bulbs. They joined my HomeKit based network easily and the colors were vivid. I wanted to like these bulbs, but ultimately they let me down.
1. I think the proliferation of trackers on the Internet is a problem, so I run AdGuard Home on my network to block trackers and ads. The Nanoleaf app errored both in account creation and on downloading new scenes to the bulbs until I disabled the protection. I have a lot of what home devices, though, and no other app for those devices has run into this problem.
2. The app itself constantly errored. It would error changing a bulb’s state or even just updating to show the current state. These failures were different from the tracking prevention errors in that either immediately retrying the action (or in some cases, killing the app and relaunching it) resolved the issues.
3. Of my 3 bulbs, 1 has an issue where it won’t completely shut off. It remains with a faint bluish white glow regardless of what color the bulb was when it hit the “off” signal. This glow doesn’t go away until power is fully cut to the bulb. Both the Nanoleaf app and the Apple Home app report the bulb is off but it’s still emitting light.
4. I contacted Nanoleaf support about this issue. After the standard “try a factory reset and re-pair the bulb” answer I expected, the support rep demanded a video proving that I’d actually done the factory reset. The mistrust and hassle combined with the above issues was the final straw and I immediately returned all 3 bulbs.
I’m done with Nanoleaf.
